messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Structured (min,+)-Convolution And Its Applications For The Shortest Vector, Closest Vector, and Separable Nonlinear Knapsack Problems The article was prepared within the framework of the Basic Research Program at the National Research University Higher School of Economics (HSE).

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this work we consider the problem of computing the (min,+)(\min,+)-convolution of two sequences a𝑎a and b𝑏b of lengths n𝑛n and m𝑚m, respectively, where n≥m𝑛𝑚n\geq m. We assume that a𝑎a is arbitrary, but bi=f​(i)subscript𝑏𝑖𝑓𝑖b_{i}=f(i), where f​(x):[0,m)→ℝ:𝑓𝑥→0𝑚ℝf(x)\colon[0,m)\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}} is a function with one of the following properties: 1. the linear case, when f​(x)=β+α⋅x𝑓𝑥𝛽⋅𝛼𝑥f(x)=\beta+\alpha\cdot x; 2. the monotone case, when f​(i+1)≥f​(i)𝑓𝑖1𝑓𝑖f(i+1)\geq f(i), for any i𝑖i; 3. the convex case, when f​(i+1)−f​(i)≥f​(i)−f​(i−1)𝑓𝑖1𝑓𝑖𝑓𝑖𝑓𝑖1f(i+1)-f(i)\geq f(i)-f(i-1), for any i𝑖i; 4. the concave case, when f​(i+1)−f​(i)≤f​(i)−f​(i−1)𝑓𝑖1𝑓𝑖𝑓𝑖𝑓𝑖1f(i+1)-f(i)\leq f(i)-f(i-1), for any i𝑖i; 5. the piece-wise linear case, when f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) consist of p𝑝p linear pieces; 6. the polynomial case, when f∈ℤd⁡[x]𝑓superscriptℤ𝑑𝑥f\in\operatorname{\mathbb{Z}}^{d}[x], for some fixed d𝑑d. To the best of our knowledge, the cases 4–6 were not considered in literature before. We develop true sub-quadratic algorithms for them. We apply our results to the knapsack problem with a separable nonlinear objective function, shortest lattice vector, and closest lattice vector problems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Solving the shortest vector problem in 2n time using discrete gaussian sampling",
        "Solving the closest vector problem in 2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} time–the discrete gaussian strikes again!",
        "A sieve algorithm for the shortest lattice vector problem",
        "Sampling short lattice vectors and the closest lattice vector problem",
        "Segment tree",
        "Some sieving algorithms for lattice problems",
        "Capacitated Dynamic Programming: Faster Knapsack and Graph Algorithms",
        "Better approximations for tree sparsity in nearly-linear time",
        "Fast algorithms for knapsack via convolution and prediction",
        "Dynamic programming",
        "Sampling methods for shortest vectors, closest vectors and successive minima",
        "Necklaces, convolutions, and x+y𝑥𝑦x+y",
        "Faster knapsack algorithms via bounded monotone min-plus-convolution",
        "Smallest k-enclosing rectangle revisited",
        "Clustered integer 3sum via additive combinatorics",
        "Deterministic apsp, orthogonal vectors, and more: Quickly derandomizing razborov-smolensky",
        "Faster min-plus product for monotone instances",
        "On problems equivalent to (min,+)(\\min,+)-convolution",
        "Integer programming, lattice algorithms, and deterministic volume estimation",
        "Enumerative lattice algorithms in any norm via m-ellipsoid coverings",
        "Covering cubes and the closest vector problem",
        "Proximity Results and Faster Algorithms for Integer Programming Using the Steinitz Lemma",
        "Improved methods for calculating vectors of short length in a lattice, including a complexity analysis",
        "An FPTAS for the ΔΔ\\Delta-Modular Multidimensional Knapsack Problem",
        "FPT-algorithms for some problems related to integer programming",
        "On δ𝛿\\delta-modular integer linear problems in the canonical form and equivalent problems",
        "Algorithms for the shortest and closest lattice vector problems",
        "Improved analysis of kannan’s shortest lattice vector algorithm",
        "Algorithms to construct minkowski reduced and hermite reduced lattice bases",
        "On integer programming and convolution",
        "On integer programming, discrepancy, and convolution",
        "Minkowski’s convex body theorem and integer programming",
        "Improved dynamic programming in connection with an fptas for the knapsack problem",
        "Knapsack Problems",
        "Combinatorial optimization",
        "Complexity of Linear Operators",
        "On the Fine-Grained Complexity of One-Dimensional Dynamic Programming",
        "On lower bounds for the maximum consecutive subsums problem and the (min,+)(\\min,+)-convolution",
        "Fast approximation algorithms for knapsack problems",
        "Shortest lattice vectors in the presence of gaps",
        "Faster exponential time algorithms for the shortest vector problem",
        "A deterministic single exponential time algorithm for most lattice problems based on voronoi cell computations",
        "Fast lattice point enumeration with minimal overhead",
        "Fast fourier transform and its applications to integer knapsack problems",
        "Sieve algorithms for the shortest vector problem are practical",
        "Dynamic programming revisited: Improving knapsack algorithms",
        "On the computation of lattice vectors of minimal length, successive minima and reduced bases with applications",
        "Knapsack and subset sum with small items",
        "Solving the shortest lattice vector problem in time 2^ 2.465 n",
        "Theory of linear and integer programming",
        "Finding the closest lattice point by iterative slicing",
        "Near optimal algorithms for computing Smith normal forms of integer matrices",
        "Smooth strongly convex interpolation and exact worst-case performance of first-order methods",
        "Faster all-pairs shortest paths via circuit complexity",
        "A survey of solving svp algorithms and recent strategies for solving the svp challenge",
        "Computing the Smith forms of integer matrices and solving related problems"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Structured (min,+)-Convolution And Its Applications For The Shortest Vector, Closest Vector, and Separable Nonlinear Knapsack Problems The article was prepared within the framework of the Basic Research Program at the National Research University Higher School of Economics (HSE)., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
